articles.title: Jake Scott
articles.contents:
Jake Scott
          
          
          Home
          Projects
          CV
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Jake Scott
            
            
              
                
                    
                      
                        LinkedIn
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Twitter
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        GitHub
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Email
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            Welcome to my personal website! I currently work as a Senior Research Assistant for the Monetary Studies Section of the Federal Reserve Board, where I contribute to every stage of the research and data analysis process; from building reliable and reusable data pipelines, to visualizing and analyzing complex data sets, to building, running, and maintaining econometric models.
            I graduated in 2020 from Colgate University, where I studied economics and political science. It is there that I first fell in love with data science in general and with R in particular. Since then, I have done countless academic, professional, and personal projects using R, R Markdown, R Shiny, and amazing packages like {tidyverse}, {tidytext}, {ggplot}, and more.
            Prior to my current position, I worked as a research intern at the Hamilton Project at the Brookings Institution, as a data research intern at Burgiss, and as a data intern at the Data Collaboratory. I have also done work raising money as a student caller, doing research as a research assistant and coauthor with a professor, knocking on doors as a political canvasser, and teaching students as a economics tutor. The through line of all of this work, as well as my personal projects, is a deep interest in using data to understand the world and to communicate with others, particularly in the realm of public policy and the economy. I also just really enjoy taking unique and messy data, cleaning it, and generating pretty visualizations that at least one other person will look at and think “neat”.
            Outside of work and data, I enjoy reading (sci fi and non-fiction are my one two punch these days- Zones of Thought series anyone?), getting my heartbroken by the Giants, Mets, and Sixers, and going fishing (freshwater only, the ocean is too scary). Please feel free to reach out if you have any questions about my work, if you think I could help your team, or if you just want to chat about R or anything else!
          
        
      
    

    
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Jake Scott

articles.title: My Projects
articles.contents:
Shiny Apps




Coronavirus Tracker Shiny App


Shiny web app that allows users to see Covid-19 cases and deaths at the national, state, and county level.






Prototype Spotify Analysis Application


Shiny web app that allows user to input their Spotify username and analyze the characteristics of their music.






Live 2020 Election Night Model


Shiny web app that fed real-time election data into the Economist Election Model and presented the resulting live win probabilities by state.




Medium Articles




He Dies, She Sucks


An Analysis of Gender and Language in Songs on Spotify.






What's in a Word?


Why tf-idf sometimes fails to accurately capture word importance, and what we can use instead.




Academic Articles




(Not) Working 9 to 5: Using Music Characteristic and Song Lyric
Data to Predict Initial Claims


Explored whether the features and sentiment of popular music in a given week could predict initial claims, using Lasso.






The Endogeneity of the Natural Rate of Growth in the United
States


Applied Okun's Equation and Thirlwall's Reversal Method to quarterly data on unemployment and gross domestic product in the United States from 1948 to 2019 in order to test the assumption that the natural rate of growth is exogenous to actual growth






Measurement Sensitivity in Field-of-Study Mismatch Research


Use data from the National Survey of College Graduates in simple linear regression and linear probability models to demonstrate that the predicted causes and consequences of field-of-study mismatch are highly sensitive to how one measures mismatch itself.
